title: The Hackathon I Swore Off ‚Äî and the Exhaustion That Mostly Compiled
content_html:
ü¶Ñ I know today is technically Copilot day, but honestly? I don't have space for another technical thought in my head right now. In case you missed it, I decided on a whim to submit a project in the n8n/BrightData hackathon.

By itself, it's not saying much. But lifting a 10-year self-imposed hackathon ban is not a light thing for somebody whose version of all-in means every last ounce of everything I had was put into that one project over those two weeks.

So instead of technical today, I've decided it's story time üòá Welcome to my only slightly dramatized retelling of true events. I'll explain why I don't do hackathons plus the thing that ultimately changed my mind.

So, pull up a chair. I‚Äôll start at the beginning of the end. ü™ëüé¢

Baby Bottles and Fry Baskets üë∂üçî

In 2008, my son was born. That was the time warp. Just a jump to the left, a step to the right, and suddenly my life wasn‚Äôt mine anymore.

üòµ‚Äçüí´ Parenthood is the only true overnight shift. One day you‚Äôre yourself, the next you‚Äôre permanently on call for a 7lb CEO who screams about everything.

At that point I was still sticking it out in restaurants ‚Äî where I'd been for close to ten years. It was long hours, long drives, and I had very little to show for it.

By January 2011, I was running on fumes and sheer force of will. Then the snowstorm hit. Everything was frozen, and there I was, alone, opening the restaurant. I ran the whole place myself: front line, back line, fry station, drive-thru, you-name-it.

ü¶Ñ "Can't" has never been in my vocabulary. By all accounts I should have stayed home that day, but I wasn't about to let a little ice stop me from doing my job. The fact that I was alone was beyond my control. So I did what I knew to do, in any way I could make it happen.

People were waiting at least thirty minutes, minimum, because one person can only move so fast, but the line just kept coming. At some point in the middle of that non-stop chaos, I looked up and saw my drive-thru customers standing inside.

üö¶ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Guess they‚Äôd been stuck out there long enough because before I knew what happened, a small group had collected in the lobby watching me sprint around like it was a personal comedy show.

In the moment, we made the best of it. We laughed, we joked, and I ran my ass off. Restaurants aren‚Äôt designed to run solo, but I made it work.

That day I remember clearly ‚Äî the day the rest of the world was shut down and I realized the joke was on me. There I was running a one-woman circus while everyone else got to stay home.

I asked myself one question: What exactly are you doing here?

A few months later, I finally walked away, for good.

The Student Loan Circus üéìüí∏

That summer, I went back to school. Student loans as the only source of income ‚Äî my lifeline. Most days, daycare covered things. Some days it didn‚Äôt.

And there I was: the older student dragging a kid into class, existing in a universe completely separate from everyone else.

üëü Their concerns were about parties and weekend plans. Mine were homework checks, missing shoes, and bills that didn‚Äôt pay themselves.

That was the dichotomy of my reality back then. My life just didn't fit into their box. But by junior or senior year, I‚Äôd settled into a rhythm.

Then came the group project.

The monster assignment. Sixty percent of the final grade hanging over all of us. The professor‚Äôs grand strategy? Hands up, step back, ‚Äúdo your thing.‚Äù Great...

ü¶Ñ Seriously, it was chaos dressed up as independence. Pick your projects, pick your teams, no submissions accepted after the deadline for any reason. I should have known hope was limited at that point.

That‚Äôs when I suddenly became popular. The same people who‚Äôd barely looked my way all semester were now lining up to hitch their wagon to my grade. And of course, they wanted me to lead. Leadership wasn‚Äôt an issue ‚Äî I‚Äôd been doing that for years.

ü§® So y‚Äôall want me in charge? Fine. But here are the ground rules: I‚Äôm not guessing, we‚Äôre not bouncing dates around, and certain nights are simply not happening. We meet weekly. We get it done. We move on. Period.

Everyone nodded, even the professor (who I involved early on just in case things went sideways) gave me the ‚Äúsounds good‚Äù approval. For a moment, I actually thought we had a workable agreement. I was wrong.

What followed was six weeks of circus hell. I brought calendars, agendas, timelines. They brought excuses. Too busy. Wrong night. Maybe later.

üòñ I've never been so amazed at people claiming to work! They shuffled meetings around like rearranging the board was the same thing as playing the game. And then acted like they deserved extra credit for their trouble.

Meanwhile, my reality lived in another universe: making sure homework got done, hunting down missing shoes, figuring out dinner on nights when the loans had already run dry.

The gap between what they thought mattered and what I was actually carrying was ludicrous.

ü§Ø To this day, I still don‚Äôt know what half of them were even trying to say. All I knew was project due and kid at home. Anything beyond that simply didn't factor into the equation.

The Kicker üí•

When I thought maybe I could finally breathe, the peer reviews landed:

  • Failure to communicate. Really? I had a plan mapped out since day one. Emails and group texts were constantly ignored, but somehow that's my fault?
  • Doesn‚Äôt work well with teams. Teams that don‚Äôt show up aren‚Äôt teams. At that point it‚Äôs just me, and if it‚Äôs me, I get it done. That‚Äôs the whole story.
  • Can‚Äôt handle pressure. My favorite.

üî• You want pressure? I‚Äôll let you babysit my kid, pay my bills, worry about classes and day care, and then we‚Äôll talk about pressure.

The fact that your last-minute date took you away from the project? That‚Äôs not pressure. That‚Äôs stupidity and not my problem.

I was livid. The immaturity was staggering. This was not the class I thought I‚Äôd signed up for. So I marched back to the professor ‚Äî the same one who‚Äôd nodded at my ground rules like they were gospel ‚Äî expecting backup.

Instead, I got a ‚Äúsolution.‚Äù Maybe, he suggested, I should try a group activity. ü§Øüò±ü§¨

Translation: hackathon.

The Hackathon I Swore Off üçïüíª

A hackathon? Because obviously the cure for dealing with people who never show up is to lock me in a room with them for forty-eight hours straight. Brilliant.

But this wasn‚Äôt optional. Those peer reviews weren‚Äôt just comments, they were baked into the grade. My arguments didn‚Äôt matter.

üòë Agree or not, I had to make up for the fact that my so-called ‚Äúteam‚Äù ‚Äî that useless cluster of hangers-on and deadweights ‚Äî had once again barged into my life and left me holding the bag.

And the price this time was a whole weekend I didn‚Äôt have to spare.

So I did it. Two days in the lab, stale pizza boxes stacked like trophies, Mountain Dew flowing like tap water. The twenty-year-olds bounced around as if sleep was optional, while I was counting babysitting hours like poker chips and wondering how many cups of coffee equal a nap.

üå™Ô∏è It was sheer chaos, and not the good kind.

I got to know people, sure, maybe even understood them a little better. But I was exhausted and my price was sitting at home without me while I watched people bluff their way through the night.

By the end I could barely remember my own name. And I walked out swearing: never again. Not unless I could give it one hundred percent ‚Äî which I knew I couldn‚Äôt, not while a six-year-old still needed me every moment of every day.

Until Now üîÑ‚è≥

Fast-forward to 2025. My son‚Äôs grown, living with his dad, and for the first time in nearly twenty years, I have time that actually belongs to me. Then along comes this challenge: n8n, agents, scrapers ‚Äî basically my bucket list wrapped in one neat little package.

So I broke my rule. WakaTime says I spent more than a hundred hours in two weeks, and that doesn‚Äôt even count the black hole of time lost to the n8n UI ‚Äî or my day job that doesn‚Äôt allow time off for my randomness (no matter how forgiving they are of my standups). Nights bled into four-thirty in the morning. Work still started at nine. Weekends turned into catch-up lies I told myself to feel better.

üé® I coded until my brain short-circuited, then wandered off to Leonardo to play with color because apparently sleep deprivation makes me an artist.

That‚Äôs the thing about hackathons: they chew you up. The clock never stops, and you‚Äôre not polishing anything ‚Äî it‚Äôs MVP or bust. The urge to overbuild doesn‚Äôt go away, but the deadline keeps you honest.

And the prize money? Forget it. If that‚Äôs your motivation, just get a job. At least those checks clear. The real payoff is the exhaustion you somehow enjoy, the kind where you know you emptied the tank and came out standing anyway.

ü´© So yeah, I‚Äôm wrecked and my brain owes me four days of sleep.

But unlike that overnight hackathon years ago, I didn‚Äôt walk away muttering ‚Äúnever again.‚Äù This time I realized I‚Äôd come full circle. Back then, the rule was survival. With a kid, student loans, and no margin for error, I couldn‚Äôt afford to burn myself out for fun.

Now, I finally could. And it turns out I didn‚Äôt just survive it ‚Äî I loved it. üíü

When Survival Turns Into Choice üß≠

And maybe that‚Äôs the truth hiding in all of this: ‚Äúnever again‚Äù usually just means ‚Äúnot right now.‚Äù

It‚Äôs okay to slam the door shut, to swear something off loudly enough that everyone hears you ‚Äî sometimes that‚Äôs survival. But don‚Äôt be surprised when the same thing comes knocking again years later.

And who knows? Maybe the next time it shows up, it brings something a little different with it. ü´∂

Ashley Childress

SSE @ Home Depot. Specialize in distributed backend systems. Happy and content playing second - all of the freedom and none of the responsibility!

üõ°Ô∏è Responsible AI Statement (RAI)

This post was drafted with the assistance of AI. The memories, chaos, and full-circle exhaustion are mine. The words were built together in the style you just read.
description: The hackathon I said I‚Äôd never do again turned exhaustion into code.

ü¶Ñ FYI: I updated this after the fact‚ÄîI did plan two full weeks down to the minute‚Äîbut I didn‚Äôt plan for not having the data or not having a solid backup when it didn‚Äôt arrive. Also, I lost half a day to Figma‚Äôs decorative quicksand. The rushed thing I pasted to make the buzzer didn‚Äôt sound like me, so this is the version I can live with (and you can actually read for fun). ü™Ñ

What I Built

Underfoot (my stubborn little ChatPot) is a chatbot that finds locals-only, off-the-map places you won‚Äôt see on Yelp or TripAdvisor. You give it a location and intent (music, coffee, hiking, spider farms‚Ä¶) and it returns unique results with a Stonewalker rating. Each query also adds anonymous whispers to the cache, so the dataset grows as people use it. üéØ

GitHub Repository ‚Äî docs, flows, screenshots

Underfoot Chat ‚Äî The Stonewalker Agent (try it)

Underfoot ‚Äî the locals-only treasure hunter üéí

I didn‚Äôt try to cram this into a weekend; I mapped two weeks like a flight plan. The part that snapped first was the one I trusted too much: a data preload that was ‚Äúready‚Äù on paper and nowhere in reality. My beautiful schedule grew a crater where the testing window used to be, and from there it was just me, the agent, the caches, and a lot of swearing said lovingly at my own ambition. üß≠

The whisper-network: project background üìº

Late ‚Äô90s / early 2000s Georgia, when cell phones were for emergencies and you rationed the battery like it owed you money. My brother and I chased off-the-wall spots through a whisper network: backyard mini-festivals with passwords in the backs of free magazines, odd museums, ghost tours that were either hilariously fake or so real you quietly recalibrated your cosmology on the drive home. Too public and the cops came; too secret and the field stayed empty. We loved that balance.

Underfoot bottles that energy. You give the resident Stonewalker an intent you actually feel (‚Äúlive music,‚Äù ‚Äúodd museums,‚Äù ‚Äústrange gardens,‚Äù ‚Äúspider farm‚Äù) plus a location. It crawls the not-obvious places first, normalizes the messy HTML, then returns a ranked list that says, ‚Äúthis is probably your kind of weird‚Äîgo now.‚Äù üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

The ‚Äúcatch‚Äù: sometimes these events haven‚Äôt been discovered yet‚Äî that's how these things work. Besides, a chatbot can‚Äôt politely wait for scraping, so every {intent, location} pair sends out separate whispers that build the cache for that combo. The next person‚Äôs list is a little louder and a little wilder than the last. üîÅ

I can‚Äôt do simple (and I stopped pretending otherwise) üß∂

I promise ‚Äútiny demo,‚Äù and five minutes later I have: an ADR (revised twice), a color palette in Leonardo, three caches, and a Future Enhancements page that looks like a subway map someone cried coffee onto. It‚Äôs not scope creep; it‚Äôs scope pre-planning. I need to see the whole creature to ship a slice.

Vibe-coding lasted maybe two minutes. Copilot drafted the UI, I took a scenic (unnecessary) tour through Figma, flirted with Stitch, sprinted to n8n because hosted chat looked fast, missed my UI and dragged it back, and somewhere in there I wrote the agent I actually wanted‚Äîdecisions like a product, not a science-fair trifold. üß™

Why I don‚Äôt do hackathons (and why I did this one anyway) ‚è±Ô∏è

Hackathons want a snapshot; I build ecosystems. They want ‚ÄúFriday by midnight‚Äù; I want to label the stations, run one line today, and the others next week. I joined anyway because this is the exact agent I‚Äôve wanted to build for months. It was fun‚Äîand it reminded me why trusting a green checkbox you don‚Äôt control is a dice roll. üü©

What it looks like ‚Äî the sprint with real nouns üßµ

Two mouths, one brain:

  • n8n Hosted Chat (discovered late, used constantly)
  • A tiny Copilot-assisted React UI once I get this deployed and working the way it does in my head. I will update with this link too.

Both funnel free-form requests into { intent, location }.

Then:

  • Fetch from the non-mainstream first (Facebook events that behave, Reddit posts that map to places or pop-ups, a growing ‚Äúweird web‚Äù list living in Obsidian).
  • Parse with minimal markup assumptions (HTML changes when you blink).
  • De-dupe with URL + fuzzy geo (and strip tracking sludge).
  • Score with the decimal Stonewalker blend: uniqueness ‚Ä¢ locality ‚Ä¢ recency ‚Ä¢ intent-fit.
  • Cache to Supabase (scraping the same planet twice is a sin).

I hit n8n‚Äôs memory ceiling right when the first end-to-end run smiled at me. Reflex: vectors + RAG + tidy GCP attic. Reality: the clock. I did the boring, correct thing‚Äîpull less, trim sooner, cache earlier. Two caches unlocked; the third is a miniboss I‚Äôll beat when I‚Äôm not running on midnight. üß±

AI agents: saints on Monday, goblins on Tuesday üëæ

Agents in the system and agents helping build the system‚Äîboth truths can be true in the same hour:

  • ChatGPT yanked me out of holes, then cited docs from a neighbor universe ten minutes later.
  • Copilot went license-dark mid-sprint‚Äîpeak front-end day timing.
  • Leonardo kept momentum by letting me see the brand when the plumbing got gnarly.
  • Various chat boxes (n8n, Bright Data, Supabase) were great rubber ducks until they hallucinated syntax.

Rule that saved me: no agent writes straight to storage. The normalizer is the law. Drafts can be flammable; data cannot. üßØ

The cache: Sheets vs Supabase (be a database, not a vibe) üóÑÔ∏è

I tried to keep the prototype in Google Sheets because it was there and felt simple. Simple lied. As soon as you care about de-dupe, TTLs, hit/miss tracking, and ‚Äúplease don‚Äôt melt anyone‚Äôs hobby site,‚Äù you need grown-up storage. I pivoted to Supabase, met Row-Level Security (RLS) and grants like a mini-boss in a fresh dungeon (v17 feels spicier), learned just enough to stop tripping over my new underfoot schema, and came out with two caches behaving‚Äîand a third that now knows the sound of my footsteps. ü™™

Underfoot belongs in your pocket (laptops were the proving ground) üì±

It runs on a computer because that‚Äôs where the tools live, but Underfoot is meant for your phone‚Äîa ‚Äúyou‚Äôre already out, what‚Äôs weird nearby?‚Äù companion. One-tap location, swipeable cards you can skim at a red light (responsibly), save/share that doesn‚Äôt fight you, and a quiet toggle: ‚Äúnudge me when something odd appears within five miles.‚Äù

Path: PWA now (installable, offline last results, Share Target) ‚Üí push later (saved intents ‚Üí ‚Äúnew oddities near you‚Äù) ‚Üí Expo wrap with haptics and deep links like underfoot://place/:id so maps feel native. üß≠

What I did wrong (say it out loud) üß®

  • Trusted an external preload without a Plan B. The curated 2.3M rows never landed; my testing window vanished; I rewrote for ‚Äúfetch + cache‚Äù and paid the polish tax. üîå
  • Spent a half-day in Figma I couldn‚Äôt spare. Respect to UX; for me it was decorative quicksand. üé®
  • Let ‚ÄúCloudflare will be easy‚Äù live rent-free. It wasn‚Äôt. Keep the UI small; add a tiny Worker proxy only where needed. ‚òÅÔ∏è
  • Left Copilot tied to work. Running out of credits mid-sprint felt like knitting with oven mitts. üß§
  • Underestimated n8n memory. Fixed by budgeting data like money: pull less, trim sooner, cache earlier. üßÆ
  • Structured output optimism. Agents can do it, but the normalizer must be the bouncer from hour one. üìá

ü¶Ñ I still had a blast, learned a ton, and might even do it again‚Äîafter a nap and a vacation from permissions dialogs. üåô

Future plans (also in the repo) üß±

High-impact next: dataset preload I control (seeded batches), vector search via pgvector once the pipeline is boring, Google Places (Text/Nearby + Details) through the same normalizer, and a curated ‚Äúweird web‚Äù seed list (40‚Äì50 URLs you wouldn‚Äôt know to google, scheduled fetcher, quality scoring so the noisy ones get benched). üß∞

Cache-first response: the Whisper Network runs in the background, but the agent should hit the cache first. Update the prompt/flow to enforce cache ‚Üí live tools.

Cache management planning: I put a lot of design work into how the cache could be structured to allow for future RAG-type navigation, along with simpler embeds for straight vector search. However, I put zero thought (asides from "I need to think about that at some point") into actually managing it after the data is there. For now, it's all dependent on a merge that's unique by URL.

  • That "unique" URL isn't very reliable and needs a better "smart" dedupe system
  • I took a limited hour-ish aside through the land of TTL in Google Sheets (not at all recommended, by the way) and learned that any way I tried to make it work it always had the same result = terrible idea. That's how Supabase got involved, but ultimately broke things worse than fixing them. I probably should have left it alone.

Localization: right now it returns the first geocoder result for speed. Flesh this out so results match what people meant, not just what a geocoder guessed.

Experience: transparent Stonewalker scoring you can peek and tweak; richer cards (images, tags, map snaps, save/share lists, quick filters); a quieter Discord bot that delivers value, not noise; mobile that respects thumbs and daylight. ‚ú®

Reliability: Normalization 2.0 is the law; a tiny ‚Äúrepair‚Äù agent only when validation fails; better cross-source entity linking so ‚ÄúThe Old Mill‚Äù is one place‚Äînot fourteen. üîê

Technical Stuff

  • System Instructions: Stonewalker persona ‚Äî hybrid nature/tech guide with a maps + travel focus.
  • Model: GPT-4.1-mini (full model as backup).
  • Memory/Cache: normalized results for reuse (v2.0); prototype began in Google Sheets.
  • Nodes: HTTP Request, Function (normalize/de-dupe), Discord notifier. Bright Data Verified node was great when it fit; I often swapped to plain HTTP for unusual flows.
  • Central AI agent: The Stonewalker.
    • I had a separate data-only agent; it took too long for mediocre results. After cache reliability + maps data, I‚Äôll revisit.
  • Triggers: Webhook (custom UI) + n8n Chat (convenience).
  • Sources: internal cache (in progress), Google Maps SERP (fallback), Google SERP, Reddit, Facebook events, pre-approved secondary sources (future).
  • Output: structured parser + secondary normalizer.
    • I went back and forth on structured output; docs warn against strict schemas with agents. The normalizer stays the final authority.
  • Error handling: Discord notifier‚Äîuseful, loud; needs formatting + routing love.
  • Planned: Bright Data Google Maps dataset (delivered 2025-09-01 03:43 PDT ‚Äî thanks, team).

Screenshots üñºÔ∏è

Live link: https://checkmarkdevtools.app.n8n.cloud/webhook/d92bc454-8f78-4471-ae25-ffa0c9bb87b3/chat

üõ°Ô∏è R.A.I. ‚Äî Responsible AI (how this stays good on purpose)

  • Transparency: model-generated text is obvious in context; ranked results cite sources; Stonewalker scores are explainable (uniqueness ‚Ä¢ locality ‚Ä¢ recency ‚Ä¢ intent-fit) with tunables coming. üîç
  • Privacy: no PII required; anonymous intent + coarse location only; one-click ‚Äúforget me‚Äù clears local cache and server traces tied to your session. ü´•
  • Respect: honor robots.txt, rate limits, and site TOS; prefer official APIs; link back, don‚Äôt lift; no paywalls or wholesale republishing. üßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è
  • Safety: filter obviously harmful/illegal content and adult venues by default; opt-in gates for edgier categories; down-rank chains; spotlight genuinely local listings. üßØ
  • Hallucination guard: agents don‚Äôt write to storage; a deterministic normalizer validates/repairs/rejects before anything lands; uncertainty is surfaced in the UI. üß™
  • Security: secrets live server-side; least-privilege keys; redacted logs; regular rotation. üõ°Ô∏è
  • Crawl with manners: staggered schedules, backoff, polite concurrency so nobody‚Äôs hobby site gets melted. üê¢

ü¶Ñ Confession: Yes I cheated ‚Äî I let ChatGPT write the initial submission, which honestly I didn't even have time to read. There is no telling what was on it, but I know it wasn't mine and it was making me crazy. ü§™ So please, do not judge this writing as part of whatever scoring happens with the project. It was all done after the deadline.

Last updated: 2025-09-01. If I miss the mark on any of this, file an issue and I‚Äôll fix it._ ‚úÖ

Epilogue üìù

Half of what I attempted was a bad idea‚Äîwhich is why I deferred the other half on purpose‚Äîand somehow I still had the best time. I‚Äôm tired in the satisfying way. I want a nap and I want to open my phone in a random city and hear Stonewalker whisper ‚Äúturn left.‚Äù That‚Äôs how I know I‚Äôm not done‚Äîjust paused long enough to tell you what really happened. üåÜ

üß†üí• The Oomph (mic-drop)

The clock ran out; the curiosity didn‚Äôt. Underfoot / Stonewalker already finds the odd little places that make a town feel alive, and the desk was just a proving ground because your pocket is the point‚Äîone tap, one intent, a handful of cards that feel like a friend leaning in to whisper, psst, go here. üåô

title: What in the World Is GitHub Coding Agent?
content_html:
ü¶Ñ You know, I've been ready to write this post for ages. This is the one thing that got me hooked on AI to begin with, and I'm still obsessed. But now that I'm here? I'm almost, almost too tired to even enjoy it. And because I'm a ride-or-die kind of person ‚Äî either all in or over it yesterday ‚Äî we're just going to dive headfirst into the shallow end. No holding back ‚Äî I hope you're ready! üõü

Your 10-minute 101 to get you started with autonomous AI ‚è∞

Honestly? there's no way I can cover everything about GitHub Coding Agent in one go. So, for this post üëá, we're doing the "just enough to be dangerous" thing. I'll hit you with the absolute must-knows, show you how to get started (in 10 minutes or less), and hopefully, not put you to sleep in the process (or myself!).

My goal is to give you a "preview teaser" so you can go play, explore a bit, and maybe even tackle that hack time project you keep putting off. But whatever you do, please don't think this is your all-inclusive pass to go wild on production code. ü´°

Coding Agent ‚â† Agent Mode ü§™

Okay, let's get something straight right off the bat, because these names are just asking for trouble. Yes, they both have "GitHub" and "Agent" in the name. And yes, they're both powered by Claude Sonnet 4, but that's where the similarities stop. Agent Mode is for in-IDE use, a bit like a sidekick who waits for you to tell it what to do next. Coding Agent? It's the whole show ‚Äî a full-on autonomous workflow that runs on its own dedicated VM.

üí° ProTip: Custom instructions and prompt techniques are the secret sauce here. This is true for any Gen-AI tool, but it's especially critical with Coding Agent, which will just keep guessing until it runs out of steam or thinks the job is done. Don't let it run wild without a map!

Don't worry, Coding Agent is designed with safety in mind. It's an incredibly contained, safe version of the "autonomous coding" experiment I ran on my own a while back. I spent 45 days arguing with a thing I wired up on my laptop, and I worked harder then than on any other project I've built before or since.

Why? Because I didn't want to just listen to what people were saying about AI ‚Äî I needed to see it for myself.

ü¶Ñ And that, my friends, is why I'm here volunteering as your guide. If you get stuck, hit me up! I've probably tried it that way plus three other insane ideas before I found one that mostly worked üôÉ

Safety First, Chaos Second üõ°Ô∏è

I know, I know... I just spent a whole paragraph telling you how much I love this thing, and now I'm gonna give you the other half of the equation.

I'm all for pushing a new tool to its absolute limit, just to see what happens. It reminds me of my favorite Hunter S. Thompson quote ‚Äî which I slightly mangled to get a SFW version ‚Äî but the core truth remains:

When you find a new, beautiful wave, the tendency is to push it as far as you can.

So, how far can you push GitHub Coding Agent? Pretty far, but there are a few things you need to know first.

1. Just Because You Can, Doesn't Mean You Should

This tool can absolutely excel, but it requires the right prompt, instructions, and general setup. If you're looking to dive into some legacy code to see what's what, or maybe you want a safe playground to mess around in, then this is your guy!

But if you're thinking about using it to fix a production bug, especially when you're on a tight deadline, you probably (aka absolutely, most definitely) want to reconsider. Treat this as a "learn how this works" project, not a "throw it at a problem and hope" situation.

2. Your Prompt is Everything

The effectiveness of your instructions and prompt is multiplied exponentially by the complexity of your task. A great, well-thought-out set of instructions that you've carefully tweaked over weeks? Coding Agent will do fine. But if you spend 10 minutes throwing a few sentences together just to see what happens, don't be surprised when you come back to a haunted house where your beautiful little cottage of a codebase used to be.

ü¶Ñ It is an agent and when an agent doesn't know something, they guess. That's just what they do. The only thing more dangerous than an AI off the rails and hallucinating is the fact that you just turned it loose on your code all by itself.

What It's Actually Good For ‚ú®

After all those warnings, I need to make it crystal clear: this tool is not dangerous. It runs on its own virtual machine and executes safely within GitHub Actions. It has a limited environment and only has access to what you explicitly give it.

It always creates a new branch, which is a key safety feature. You can't get around it, even if you try. Trust me, I was annoyed, but the safety is worth it.

So what can you realistically use this for? Here are some of my favorite real-world use cases:

  • Documentation: Nothing has worked better for me than using Coding Agent to dive deep into a codebase and spit out test-ready use cases or a handful of detailed system architecture Mermaid diagrams. You set it loose, go get a coffee, and come back to 7-8 pages of detailed, well-researched use cases ready to be plugged in.
  • Testing: This one's a little controversial for a test-driven development purist like me, but... when you're on a deadline and you just need to get things done, you can write the code and have Coding Agent go write the tests. It's not a perfect solution, but a pull request with 28/30 passing tests is way better than one with zero tests at all. ü§´ü´£
  • Project Planning: Got a big initiative coming up? Instead of spending a week flipping through pages of dead code to figure out how it used to work, you can have Coding Agent do the heavy lifting and print out a nifty little report when it's done.

How to Get Started in 5 Minutes or Less ‚è±Ô∏è

In the interest of time and keeping this digestible, I'm going to give you the basics that will work 100% of the time. We'll dig in on some more tools next week.

GitHub has made this incredibly accessible now. You can find the new agents panel button on just about every page in GitHub: both on the home page and within any repository.

  1. Select the Repository and Base Branch: Choose the repo and the branch you want Coding Agent to work from. It will always create its own branch, so don't worry about selecting main (or a trunk-based development model) if that's your primary branch. I'm telling you, you can try to tell it not to create a branch, but it's not going to listen.

  2. Craft Your Prompt: This is not your typical conversational prompting. Coding Agent will keep guessing until it reaches what it considers to be "complete." Save yourself the headache and give it all the info up front.

  3. Submit Your Request: Every time you hit send, it's considered one premium request. This is why it's so important to be concise and provide all the context it needs upfront.

üí° ProTip: To save premium requests when reviewing Copilot's PR, go to the diff page and leave all your @copilot comments as pending. When you're ready, submit them all at once, and it will only cost you one request whether you leave two comments or 20.

A Final Warning About Responsibility üòà

Okay, one last thing. I have to let this sink in:

If it's your prompt, it's your code. Period.

If you go out and give a prompt to Copilot, ignore it for 30 minutes, do a half-hearted review, approve your own pull request, override the protection rules to push it to main, and then the codebase burns down... that's not Copilot's fault. That's your fault. Your prompt, your branch, your code, AI or not.

So, be aware, be smart, and please don't use this as an excuse to ignore the basics. Start small with documentation or tests, and work your way up.

Let's Get Real ü§®

Have you tried GitHub Coding Agent yet? What are your thoughts? Are you all in or has it been a big nope so far? Drop your wins, fails, and horror stories in the comments below. Bonus points if you link a fun code review you've got to do for Copilot. ü§™

üõ°Ô∏è AI helped (I did the heavy lifting)

This post was written by me + one suspiciously helpful robot (Gemini) + one robot firmly in the time-out corner (ChatGPT).
description: An all-in, real-world guide to GitHub‚Äôs Coding Agent‚Äîwhat it really does, what can go sideways, and why ‚Äúall in‚Äù was the only way I could learn. This is just the start of a whole series, because honestly, this rabbit hole goes deep.

title: Medium and the Blanket AI Ban üò∂
content_html:
UPDATED

Thank you, @fatherofcurses for making me stop and actually think through solutions. So I've updated my post on Medium and suggested this system that I think we all would be able to live with (your here is Medium's):

üëâ Don‚Äôt exclude everybody by default. AI ‚â† ‚Äúbad‚Äù. It can be misused, sure, but stereotyping an entire group of writers because of a few bad actors isn‚Äôt okay.

Here‚Äôs what I propose:

  • Create an AI pre-approval system.
  • If a writer wants their AI-assisted work to be eligible for your programs, let them apply.
  • Get your human reviewers involved ‚Äî tear the post apart, see if it‚Äôs worthy.
  • If it passes, give them a badge üè∑Ô∏è that automatically shows up on their page.

Now, two good things happen:

  1. Writers aren‚Äôt forced to keep disclaiming ‚ÄúAI-generated‚Äù every post ‚Äî the badge already says it.
  2. Once approved, their work is treated like everyone else‚Äôs. No blanket exclusion, just fair review.

Yes, it‚Äôs a little more work on your end. But it‚Äôs a whole lot easier to swallow ‚Äî and way more fair ‚Äî for the rest of us.

THE ORIGINAL

I‚Äôve been meaning to write this since I first saw Medium's post on Friday ‚Äî but, you know, life happens. So a little late, but I wanted to share. You tell me ‚Äî am I the crazy one here? ü´§

üëÜ Also, River has shown up in a few posts already ‚Äî the Leonardo reimagining of my blog character. She‚Äôs still missing some key features (training tokens are tapped out until the month resets), but you get the idea. üòÜ Expect a couple more tweaks coming soon.

So Friday was my chill day (rare, but they do happen) and I noticed somebody had followed me on Medium. Which is funny, because I‚Äôd already canceled my membership ‚Äî it just hadn‚Äôt expired yet. Five bucks a month isn‚Äôt exactly breaking the bank, so I thought, fine, maybe I‚Äôll toss a few posts over there alongside LinkedIn.

That was the plan. Until I landed on Medium‚Äôs homepage and saw this headline:

‚ÄúWe want your feedback: how can writers use AI to tell human stories?‚Äù

ü¶Ñ Perfect hook, right? Except two scrolls later I was fuming like I was just called in for a rollback on a Friday night. üò°

The Fine Print üîç

By the time you dig through the post, the documentation, and the linked policies, the message is clear:

  • AI as spellcheck? Totally fine. ‚úÖ
  • ChatGPT outlines and fact-checks? Approved. ‚úÖ
  • Anything more (drafting, editing, all other AI assistance)? ‚ùå
    • You‚Äôre officially outside their definition of ‚Äúwriter.‚Äù

And if you do dare use AI, you have to declare it at the very top of your post, within the first two paragraphs, and again on every image. Metadata doesn‚Äôt count.

ü¶Ñ TL;DR: If you lean on AI for anything beyond grammar, you can write on Medium, but you‚Äôll never get boosted, partnered, or featured. You can post, but you‚Äôre standing outside in the rain while everyone else gets a table inside. üçΩÔ∏è

Why It Feels Off ü§î

Look, I get it. Nobody wants a feed full of unedited AI sludge. I‚Äôm not trying to game the system either. I‚Äôm not chasing claps or badges. I write because it‚Äôs fun, because I need a break from code, and because I have opinions the world clearly needs to hear. üòâ

AI doesn‚Äôt erase my voice ‚Äî it sharpens it.

So calling everything in between spellcheck and prompt-posting off limits? No appeal, no nuance, just blanket exclusion? That‚Äôs where I‚Äôm lost.

Developers talk nonstop about AI. Colleges too. It‚Äôs a huge, messy, important conversation. And Medium ‚Äî the site that prides itself on being the ‚Äútop blogging platform‚Äù ‚Äî takes the most stereotypical, exclusionary stance possible. ChatGPT usually gets painted as the villain here, but really, it‚Äôs just the stand-in for all the tools that make the work easier.

Honestly, it feels less like quality control and more like gatekeeping. Nuance would‚Äôve made sense. Even a "don't automate your blog posts" sounds great. This? It's like they skipped gray completely and went straight to Twilight Zone monochrome.

My Reply ‚úçÔ∏è

You know I couldn‚Äôt resist. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Yes ‚Äî I dropped a response directly on Medium's front door, and linked to it right in their own discussion. That‚Äôs the only thing I‚Äôve ever published over there besides the previous post on Blogging with Bots I forwarded as an explanation.

If you want the full-on-rant version of how I pushed back, here it is:

#HumansForAI: A Story of ‚ÄúLittle Value‚Äù | by Ashley Childress | Aug, 2025 | Medium

Ashley Childress „Éª Aug 29, 2025 „Éª
Medium

Wrapping It Up üå±

I‚Äôm calmer now, but the question still bugs me. AI doesn‚Äôt erase my voice ‚Äî it just lets me shape it faster, sharper, and with a little extra spark. So if Medium can‚Äôt see that, maybe that‚Äôs their loss.

And hey, I don‚Äôt want this to be a solo rant echoing into the void either! I want to know what you think. Is this really such a crime against writing, or is Medium being willfully old-school about it?

ü¶Ñ Let‚Äôs hash it out right here ‚Äî the corner of the internet where the fun people hang around anyway.

title: Three AIs and a Funeral: My Take on GPT-5 ‚ö∞Ô∏è
content_html:
ü¶Ñ Confession time: when I first started writing this post, I was mad. Not mildly irritated, not ‚Äúeh, I‚Äôll just wait for the next patch‚Äù annoyed. I mean genuinely fed up with Copilot, ChatGPT, and everything GPT-5 in general. And if I make it to the end of this post in one piece, maybe you'll understand why.

The Funeral üëª

First, let me start this out by stating that OpenAI has officially buried the excuse that GPT can‚Äôt code. We had the funeral over the weekend. All its friends were invited. Laid to rest. Cremation done. Trees planted. Memorial service complete.

It‚Äôs done ‚Äî GPT-5 can code. Full stop.

There's no room for debate. No more hacks with pages of instructions or GPT hanging out on the sidelines because it's busy staring at the plan. OpenAI nailed it with an absolutely solid model.

Plus VS Code's release came with some more experimental features that turns the already-solid GPT-5 in to a ‚Äúsend a prompt, make a plan, deep thinking, Implementation Specialist at your service‚Äù experience. That being said, I still haven't had nearly enough time with the full model yet.

ü¶Ñ Why, you ask? Because my brilliant self left my personal account logged in while working last week. That account? It's the cheap $10 one. I burned through all my premium requests before I even noticed. ü´•

So yes, GPT-5 (the real one) passed its early test runs beautifully ‚Äî small to medium features, planning and implementation, no complaints. But the deep dive it deserves? That‚Äôs still coming ‚Äî stay tuned.

What was I doing instead of the GPT-5 deep dive? Playing the lead role in the horror story of Full House starring Kimmy Gibbler and the never-ending wall of text. üßó‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüòë

Duct Tape, Please? ü§ê

GPT-5-Mini is not bad. Let‚Äôs clear that up. For small, targeted context? For quick features? For implementing a clearly defined task with accuracy and precision? It‚Äôs great. Honestly. Kimmy Gibbler is a surprisingly solid coder.

But the output.
Oh. My. God. The. Output. ü´®üò≤üòµ‚Äçüí´

I'm talking about walls and walls of text. Waterfalls of ‚Äúlook at me, I wrote a test!‚Äù status updates flooding my chat window like it's trying to set a world record. No, Kimmy, I don‚Äôt need a play-by-play novella about the journey you took to create a three-line function.

ü¶Ñ Sure ‚Äî I started out at least trying to skim what it was saying. But my sanity didn't last long into that battle. Seriously, if I read another scroll of verbose rambling I might have retreated to some dark corner until next Tuesday.

The Standoff

At one point, it got so bad that I set up a stand-off. I told GPT something along the lines of, ‚ÄúGo check on that workflow. If it works, give me a checkmark. That‚Äôs it. If you say anything else, I‚Äôm turning you off forever.‚Äù

It complied. One lonely ‚úÖ appeared.

ü¶Ñ Victory? Maybe. For about thirty seconds. Then the rambling resumed. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Here‚Äôs what I didn‚Äôt realize at first: I had also turned on every single experimental preview feature in VS Code. That‚Äôs my usual routine ‚Äî release notes drop, I‚Äôm flipping switches left and right.

I thought I was enabling a neat little planning checklist feature. Which to be fair, I did do that... I also omitted its counterpart to internalize that chatter. Which meant the Mini chaos doubled ‚Äî and nothing I added to the prompts or instructions made a bit of difference. üò´

ü¶Ñ I even tried to tame it with a new Principal Pragmatist chat mode. Didn‚Äôt matter. Kimmy kept talking. Nonstop floods of text testing my sanity at every turn. Thanks, Kimmy.

Leatherface Joins the Party

GitHub Copilot is only part of the equation, though. Because just when I thought I‚Äôd found a rhythm there, here comes ChatGPT starring as Leatherface, chainsaw roaring, doing a happy dance all over my carefully constructed blog draft. Shredding paragraphs. Scattering virtual scraps across the room. Obliterating what had been a perfectly flowing system of prompts and edits.

ü¶Ñ I mean, this post normally would have taken me a couple of hours. Instead, three days later, I'm still wrestling Leatherface for control of my own sentences.

Commands escalated. From firm. To censored. To questioning life choices. And finally, full-on ultimatum. I even took a few hours detour with Gemini ‚Äî proof that I'm willing to go to war with an LLM over word count. (I'm also still losing that battle!)

The moral of the story? While GPT-5 is a great coder ‚Äî it is more than terrible at creative writing. So, why do we have a single model replacement for 2 completely different problems, OpenAI?

Where We Are Now

So where does that leave things?

  • GPT-5: rock-solid coder, worthy of the ‚ÄúImplementation Specialist‚Äù title, but still waiting for its fair turn in the spotlight with me.
  • Mini: great in short bursts, but do not let her narrate. Especially not with every experimental feature flipped on. Else plan for duct tape.
  • ChatGPT: still a chainsaw in a library butchering my every attempt at creative writing.

And me? Still here. Still writing. Still dragging you through the chaos with me, because apparently this is how I process the fact that we had a funeral for ‚ÄúGPT can‚Äôt code‚Äù and I celebrated it by duct-taping Gibbler and dodging Leatherface.

Sounds like a victory, right? Well, sort of. At least the tombstone is carved. ü´∂üëª

üõ°Ô∏è Responsible AI Footnote

All opinions here are my own. Real-world AI results depend on setup, context, and the occasional experimental toggle you probably shouldn‚Äôt have turned on in the first place. Test responsibly.

ü™ì Approved by Leatherface (ChatGPT).

title: Weekend Hack: Making My Blog AI-Searchable (No Flames Required) üî•üö´
content_html:
First of all ‚Äî thank you. üôè

For real. This community has been nothing but encouraging, and it was a huge surprise to end up in the top seven last week. I didn‚Äôt expect it, but it‚Äôs appreciated more than you know. ü´∂

TL;DR

If you're looking for a quick and efficient way to increase traffic to your DevTo blog posts (or anywhere else with a little tweaking)? Try my 10-minute DevTo crawly mirror. Here's how it works:

  1. Clone the repo. Enter your DevTO username as an env variable in the repo. Delete the existing gh-pages branch.
  2. Scheduled GHA Workflow off-peak or manually trigger.
  3. Static HTML hosted via GitHub Pages
  4. Canonical back to Dev

Starting With Nothing üî¶

So, this entire thing started with a conversation.

ü¶Ñ About what? I honestly can‚Äôt remember now ‚Äî Copilot, debugging, something in that ballpark. Doesn‚Äôt matter.

But somehow ‚Äî like so many of my rabbit holes ‚Äî it mutated and morphed until I wasn't exactly at the same place I had started. I really can't explain the series of events that happened after that. I blame it on curiosity more than anything, but I did the one thing I swore I'd never do: I asked ChatGPT to do a quick search ‚Äî pull one of my posts.

And... nothing. Like the post didn‚Äôt exist. üï≥Ô∏è

Okay. üòÖ Fine. Let‚Äôs take a step back. Next, I went straight to Google and typed the same thing. Results were better ‚Äî sure. Scroll, scroll, scroll... and there it was. My post. Not at the top, but alive. Win. üòè

ü¶Ñ Real talk: Do I care about being #1? No, not in the slightest. Honestly, I love my invisibility bubble ‚Äî keeps things peaceful in my corner of the internet.

But here‚Äôs the thing: invisibility and AI don‚Äôt mix. Because when I need an answer, I don‚Äôt open a browser anymore. I yell at my phone: ‚ÄúHey Google!‚Äù Or I pop into ChatGPT or Gemini.

If my posts don‚Äôt show up there, they might as well not even exist. ü´§

D√©j√† Vu üîÆ

So I‚Äôm now blessed with the knowledge that my posts are basically hiding out in the Room of Requirement ‚Äî you know it‚Äôs there, but only if the stars align. And that makes it hard to share the advice I keep repeating everywhere else that will listen:

  • ‚ÄúYes, you can use it for debugging.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúOf course it can generate the tests.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúDocs? Oh my god, PLEASE let it write the docs.‚Äù

By the time I‚Äôve said it for the fifth time, it feels like I‚Äôm stuck in reruns.

ü¶Ñ Honestly, some days I feel like I need a theme song: ‚ÄúPreviously, on AI Adventures with Ashley...‚Äù üéµüé∂

Sure. Sometimes, I let AI run wild (it's more fun that way!). My Coding Agent kills it with documentation. I even built a chat mode that plays architect ‚Äî reverse engineers a repo and spits out mermaid diagrams like it‚Äôs dealing cards in Vegas. That one runs in GitHub Actions, then opens a PR, and I'll merge once everything checks out.

But the everyday stuff? It‚Äôs not dramatic. It‚Äôs small instructions, nudges, prompts. Rinse, repeat, coffee, repeat again. ‚òïÔ∏è It's slow, incremental improvements to be just a little better than yesterday. ü§è

And what drives me absolutely up the wall? The extremes. Either ‚ÄúAI will replace every dev tomorrow‚Äù or ‚ÄúAI is useless, don‚Äôt bother.‚Äù

ü¶Ñ Honestly, it‚Äôs like sitting court-side at Quidditch ‚Äî the little guy zips across the field so fast you think you‚Äôve finally caught up, but nope. He‚Äôs already off to something else... and it‚Äôs almost always completely wrong, too. üòÖ

Writing It Down üìï

So my solution: write it down. That‚Äôs what most of these blog posts are. Whatever comes up that week ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs me digging, someone else asking, or just another repeated question ‚Äî if I haven‚Äôt covered it already, give me a week. I'll get there.

The beauty of this system? Instead of explaining everything for the tenth time, I can just say: ‚ÄúGlad you‚Äôre trying this. I think my blog might help ‚Äî here‚Äôs the link. Let me know if you‚Äôve got questions.‚Äù

See. Simple, right? üôÇ‚Äç‚ÜïÔ∏è But even that wasn‚Äôt enough, because usually by the time I arrived on scene things were in somewhat of a state already. Mostly because what AI was helping with had a knowledge cut-off of January and everything else is wading through Microsoft or GitHub docs looking for any little nibble.

So I set out to find a way to make my DevTo posts truly crawly ‚Äî without Dante's DevOps nightmares playing on repeat at the top of every hour.

ü¶Ñ Sure, I briefly considered the real solution ‚Äî custom website, full hosting stack, the whole front-end shebang. But I'm a backend engineer for a reason! My personal site is designed for APIs not MUI. I'd really prefer to keep it that way!

The Hack in Action üíª

So, I did what any other respectable developer would do with an extra 15 minutes and spark of an idea: I hacked it. What do you get with 3 hours, a solid round of "will OCD win again?" and ChatGPT + GitHub Copilot tag team special? Exactly zero upkeep ‚Äî mission accomplished. ‚úÖ

GHA cron ‚Üí Dev API ‚Üí static HTML ‚Üí GitHub Pages ‚Üí robots.txt

That‚Äôs it. No CSS. No fancy layout. Just static content, scheduled on a daily push. Best of all? ChatGPT could finally find my posts. Gemini too.

ü¶Ñ True story: I spent longer arguing with Leonardo to make a banner image than I did setting up the whole mirror.

Add A Little Sparkle ‚ú®

I'm in no way an expert when it comes to SEO or even scraping in general. I did happen across this tidbit in the 15 minutes of research I did on the subject. I'm still testing this to see what the impact looks like, but seems promising. üòá

In your DevTo settings, you have the option to use the current rich-text markdown editor we all know and love or, you can switch to the legacy version. It's kind of an all or nothing deal, as far as I can tell. So you either have it everywhere or nowhere. But, it does give you access to the yaml front-matter for your posts and the ability to define your own brief description instead of relying on the first ~160 words you post.

It seems like an awfully lot of work though, and I've kinda gotten used to the new markdown buttons (that I never use). So my solution? Let's just hit buttons until I find one that works. ü§ì

What's Mine is Yours üçÄ

Whether you‚Äôre after more profile views or just tired of repeating yourself like me, this trick works. You can have my quick and easy DevTO-Mirror running in less than 10 minutes. Just copy it, fork it, clone it, star it ‚Äî whatever you like. And please, avoid Dante‚Äôs DevOps while you‚Äôre at it. üî•üòà

This post is now searchable üõ°Ô∏è

Responsibly indexed by me & the robots. Fueled by coffee ‚òïÔ∏è, steered by OCD, and completely bypassed the 9th circle of hell. üî•üö´

ü¶Ñ No, I'm still not finished getting this character exactly where I want her to be for the banners. But they're so close that I had to use it. Minor tweaks still and an AI character (or several) to tag along still to come üíñ

title: Everything I Know About GitHub Copilot Instructions ‚Äî From Zero to Onboarded (For Real) ‚ö°
content_html:
Updated: Yes ‚Äî I had to change the banner. It was killing me ü§£ I'm going to get Leonardo trained with this character eventually. In the meantime ChatGPT is doing just fine (after you ignore the personality change and retraining brought on by the v5 upgrade).

ü¶Ñ I honestly hadn‚Äôt planned to write this one until next week, but the post I did write this week... disappeared. And redoing work you‚Äôve already done? Zero fun. It‚Äôs like reheating French fries ‚Äî technically edible, but you know it‚Äôs not going to be as good. So here we are, skipping the fries, and moving on!

Also, you might want a snack for this one! It's a little more in-depth than usual. And yes ‚Äî I did rate my own approach higher than Microsoft and GitHub. Obviously. üòõ

TL;DR ü™º

Stop tossing Copilot into the deep end without floaties! Write repo instructions, test them, tweak them, build them, repeat. Whether you use Microsoft‚Äôs, Coding Agent‚Äôs, or my Instructionalist, the goal‚Äôs the same: keep Copilot coloring inside your lines.

Background

This post is one part personal call-out (I really need testers üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è) and one part sequel to my most-read post All I‚Äôve Learned About GitHub Copilot Instructions (so far).

If you've never read it or if you missed some of the more recent updates (yes ‚Äî I always try to go back and call out changes whenever GitHub or VS Code changes something), then go check out the basics first before getting too deep here. If you're already up to speed? Great ‚Äî hop on in and I'll give you the grand tour! üèéÔ∏è

The original post still represents ~95% of how I handle custom instructions. I still use almost everything in it. But a few things have changed ‚Äî new ways to get started, lessons learned from letting Copilot roam ‚Äî on a leash ‚Äî in enterprise codebases, and a sharper focus on making it write what you want instead of what it thinks you might have meant.

ü¶Ñ Also, yes, shameless plug: I started an awesome-github-copilot repo. It‚Äôs still a WIP, but there are already a few gems in there. If you‚Äôre willing to be a guinea pig üêπ, reach out!

Why Repo Instructions Matter ‚ö†Ô∏èüëá

Let‚Äôs set the scene. You‚Äôve got a legacy monster app sitting in the corner. No one wants to touch it. And now a brand-new senior dev walks in the door. Would you say:

‚ÄúHey, go refactor something. Good luck!‚Äù

Of course not! But that's exactly what's happening every single time you drop Copilot in cold with zero guidance or direction about what you expect. It will produce something ‚Äî and it will produce it confidently ‚Äî and based entirely on your repo‚Äôs worst patterns. You‚Äôll get more code, faster, sure... but not at all better!

Plan an Up-Front 15 Min ‚åöÔ∏è

So instead of sending your golden senior developer off to the trenches on their first day, what if you just took 15 minutes with them? Explain why half the code is wired together like an escape room puzzle, which systems will blow up if they touch the wrong file, and why that java.io serialization is still hanging around after three Java upgrades.

That‚Äôs exactly how you should treat Copilot.

And you'll see the exact same returns from Copilot as you would any well-trained developer who's capable of reading documentation and making the right call when it matters.

ü¶Ñ Be aware: This is never going to be a "set-and-forget" system. It doesn't need constant care like a newborn (after a solid round of testing), but it's still gonna grow and change with your app. App changes = instructions change. Always!

Repo Instructions to the Rescue üö¢üõü

Repo instructions are your chance to give Copilot a tour before it starts swinging a hammer. They work everywhere Copilot runs ‚Äî IDE, GitHub.com, even mobile (according to the docs anyway). Put them in main, and suddenly everyone prompting Copilot is working from the same rules, style, and ‚Äúdon‚Äôt touch‚Äù list.

If you're thinking about simply listing best coding practices just to show Copilot where commas go? You're not using them correctly. Start thinking of these files as the de facto onboarding for any senior dev and approach them with that level of info and let the auto-formatter handle the commas and new lines.

üí° ProTip: Copilot will naturally catch on, but a quick one-liner that says "Follow rules in [eslint.config.js](./eslint.config.js)" is generally all you need to have it start checking the lint commands automatically.

Start small and don't get the file get too bloated. If you have a set of similar instructions, you can always break them out into a custom instruction file apart from the primary version. Then use applyTo in the front-matter to define which files they should be applied to.

For example, you have specific database instructions that outline constraints or upcoming planned features and you want to start "forward thinking"? Put them in .github/instructions/database.instructions.md instead of the default file and add the applyTo. Any time Copilot references one of these DAO classes, these instructions would be attached automatically.

---
applyTo: src/main/java/dao/**/*
---

# My Custom Database Instructions

The Three Best Ways to Get Started

1. Microsoft‚Äôs ‚ÄúGenerate Instructions‚Äù in VS Code (‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è)

When this first came out, I‚Äôll be honest ‚Äî I hated it. I mean, it was bad. ‚ÄúGo read the first line of every file in the repo, copy/paste them into a doc, and call it instructions‚Äù bad. It was like your coworker emailing you a Google search link instead of an actual answer.

But I have to be fair ‚Äî it‚Äôs better now. It actually reads your repo, finds the important stuff, maps out project structure, and even calls out workflows and automation. Still not perfect, but you could hand it to a new dev and they wouldn‚Äôt immediately run screaming.

üí° ProTip: Let your formatter + linter handle style rules so you don‚Äôt waste instruction space showing Copilot where commas go. Absolutely no one needs 14 examples of what JavaScript looks like in their instructions file.

How to run it:

üíª Expand for screenshots in VS Code for generating Microsoft repo instructions

In VS Code:

  1. Click the gear icon ‚öôÔ∏è at the top of the chat window.
  2. Click Generate Instructions
  3. Let it run.
  4. Then, like any responsible repo owner, trim the fluff before committing.

Alternate:

  1. Press Ctrl+Shift+P / Cmd+Shift+P.
  2. Search Chat: Generate Workspace Instructions File.

2. Coding Agent (‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è¬Ω ‚Äì creeping toward 4)

This one‚Äôs a little different ‚Äî it runs on Claude Sonnet 4, and no, you don‚Äôt get to change that. The upside? Claude‚Äôs got a good sense of architecture and implementation strategy, so it‚Äôs a bit like asking the ‚Äúbig picture‚Äù person on your team for a first draft. The downside? If you aren‚Äôt specific, it‚Äôll start guessing... and you might get a fully stocked contributor guide when you really just wanted repo setup notes.

Coding Agent is also PR-safe ‚Äî it always creates a separate branch. You could tell it ‚Äúgo wild,‚Äù walk away, and it wouldn‚Äôt touch your main branch without a pull request. Bonus ‚Äî you can prompt it with a mini-series and as long as it fits in the single prompt, it will tackle your whole list for a single premium request.

üí° ProTip: The specifics here are key. Think of it like you're leading KT. What are all the important highlights that you'll need to get the basics across? If you're not sure, it's better to omit something than be wrong or mention a maybe that will force Copilot to guess on your behalf.

How to run it:

üíª Click for screenshots on GitHub.com for generating repo instructions with Coding Agent

At GitHub.com/Copilot:

  1. Go to GitHub.com/Copilot.
  2. Click Agents in the lefthand sidebar.
  3. Pick your repo + base branch (Copilot will still make its own branch from there).
  4. Prompt it: ‚ÄúGenerate custom repository instructions for this repo‚Äù + any important specifics.

3. My ‚ÄúInstructionalist‚Äù Chat Mode (‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è, with bias admitted)

Okay, yes, I‚Äôm biased. But this thing exists because I got tired of explaining ‚Äî for the fourth or fifth time ‚Äî why every repo should have good Copilot instructions.

It‚Äôs a Q&A where you (aka the person who actually knows the repo) fill in the stuff Copilot can‚Äôt guess: your SLAs, the weird dependencies that no one touches, the ‚Äúif X happens at 3:15 AM, restart Y or the whole system falls over‚Äù kind of lore.

It writes from ‚Äúwhere we want to be,‚Äù not ‚Äúwhere we are,‚Äù and builds in things the other methods skip ‚Äî anti-patterns, testing goals, deployment notes, even gentle nudges like ‚Äúacknowledge uncertainty‚Äù when multiple solutions exist.

üì¢ Model note: This one‚Äôs running on GPT-4.1 too!

How to run it:

üíª Click for step by step instructions for loading custom chat modes in VS Code


Copy the chat mode:

  1. My repo is at github.com/anchildress1/awesome-github-copilot

  2. Find The Instructionalist chat mode (or any other chat mode you can dig up) and copy raw content

    ‚ö†Ô∏è Careful! Don't grab docs by mistake. You're looking for the file that ends in .chatmode.md

  3. Create a new chat mode in VS Code and replace default with pasted Instructionalist

  4. Select custom mode from the dropdown

  5. Prompt Copilot to begin

    ü¶Ñ Try something like Help me create repo instructions and give it time to scan your setup. Then answer as much as you can ‚Äî Copilot will filter out what it doesn't need.

    üé§ This is a perfect time to try the Speech plugin, but check the delay setting first so it doesn't send before you're ready.

The Results üêô

Microsoft in VS Code ü™º

Microsoft‚Äôs instructions were very structure-first. You get a ‚ÄúWelcome to this repository‚Äù blurb at the top (which I left out in mine, because why?) and sections like Project Structure and Key Concepts. I was surprised that it even calls out the status badge system. It‚Äôs tidy and functional. It works.

ü¶Ñ It also adds a short ‚Äúhow to turn on custom instructions‚Äù note ‚Äî which you shouldn‚Äôt need, unless you‚Äôve gone in and toggled them off on purpose before.

Coding Agent via GitHub üß©

Coding Agent‚Äôs version swaps the order around a bit and renames a few headers (although, I don‚Äôt consider ‚Äústructure‚Äù and ‚Äúprinciples‚Äù to be interchangeable ‚Äî so if you use this method, consider renaming that!) It skips the status badge part in the intro but circles back later with its own Status System section. You also get content guidelines, writing style notes, and real markdown link refs for internal docs (which is best practice).

But it also tries to sneak in a whole Contribution Guidelines section... which, let‚Äôs be honest, belongs in a CONTRIBUTING.md, not in instructions for Copilot.

ü¶Ñ This is not the first time Coding Agent has tried to add every possible document GitHub makes available during a PR. It seems to be wired into the fact that if you have a public repo, then you need all of these things to exist. I'm going to dig into this more and report back.

The Instructionalist Custom Chat Mode üì¢

My version ignores all of the ‚ÄúWelcome‚Äù and ‚ÄúStructure‚Äù boilerplate and instead jumps straight into "Purpose" and "Value". It defines chat modes, prompts, and instructions in a way that makes Copilot‚Äôs role more engaging and interactive. Copilot makes it clear these aren‚Äôt just generic AI prompts ‚Äî they‚Äôre curated for all stages of the dev process.

These don‚Äôt explicitly call out the status badge system, but it's referenced in context. And you get extras you won‚Äôt see in the other two: "Maturity Level" (so Copilot knows if the project is actively maintained or just camping in test mode), "Dependencies on Other Systems", and, yes, the occasional bit of lore. üòá Plus explicit anti-patterns and testing/deployment plans.

ü¶Ñ I have to call out this is the only version that requires the user to participate up front. So naturally it takes longer to spin up. If you're asking me? Completely worth the trade off.

Final Answer? ‚ÅâÔ∏è

When you stack them side-by-side, you can see the philosophy differences right away:

  • Microsoft: Orient Copilot by describing the map (structure, files, concepts).
  • Coding Agent: Orient Copilot by describing the rules of the game (guidelines, principles, styles).
  • My Instructionalist: Orient Copilot by describing the player‚Äôs role (purpose, value, patterns, anti-patterns).

The truth? If you completely ignore the fact that I clearly think mine is the best (because of course I do), the ideal file is actually a hybrid. A little structure from Microsoft, a little guideline clarity from Coding Agent, and a little persona and context from The Instructionalist.

Every generated file is long, so don‚Äôt be afraid to cut anything that's not adding obvious value. Save extras in a /future-review folder. Keep essentials in the main file, and for the love of your PR sanity ‚Äî update them every time something changes!

‚ö†Ô∏è Seriously, y'all! Old instructions are just as dangerous as no instructions at all!

What Else Have You Tried?

Have you tried writing instructions by hand or generating your own with Copilot yet? Whether you go Microsoft, Coding Agent, my Instructionalist, some weird hybrid of all three, or something different entirely ‚Äî I want to know what worked (and what exploded).

Drop your results, screenshots, or horror stories in the comments. Bonus points if you rate yours higher than mine. üòõ

üõ°Ô∏è Built with AI

...but only after I gave it a proper tour, told it where the coffee machine was, and warned it about the zombie curse actively infecting LLC..
